SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker-
—How many days have you been away?
—Order! The honourable member for Gippsland has been interjecting all evening. I think I gave him a view earlier that he might have to leave if he wishes to continue this.
—I quote from the Australian newspaper, which is not especially a purveyor of Australian Labor Party views:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no sacred right to refuse to identify oneself when engaging in transactions which could affect one's income tax liability.

It is a view which I think underlines the thrust of this legislation. The Government and indeed we as members of this House-and I would agree with the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) on this point-are custodians of public interest. As such, it is the responsibility of the Government to raise funds through the Australian Taxation Office and to spend that money in establishing programs in the areas of health, defence, education, community services, transport, aviation, immigration-I could go on and on-and in a whole range of other activities and to spend that money as efficiently and effectively as possible. More than a quarter of the Federal Budget every year is spent in social security. It is vital that that money which is spent in the area of social security on behalf of all Australians and for all Australians should be spent efficiently and effectively. The thrust of this legislation is to see that we raise money in the fairest possible way so that those who presently are able to avoid their tax obligations are not able to do so and that the expenditure of money is efficient and effective.

Four or five months ago in this place members of the Opposition opposed this legislation. They opposed it on the grounds that it would infringe civil liberties, that it was too expensive and for a number of other reasons. At that time they did not really have a policy or a suggestion which was an alternative. They had toyed with the tax file number, but when that was raised as an amendment in the Senate they voted against it. So, at a cost to the Australian taxpayers of $300m or $400m, because we have been waiting that long to debate the legislation again in this place, we find ourselves here again today. The honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter), the shadow Minister who has responsibility in this area, again today acknowledged the need for a more efficient identification system. He complained, as he usually does, about the costs and about the inefficiency of the Australian Tax Office and then in the last two minutes of his speech he scratched together a few strands of a new policy. Those opposite were going to tighten up this, reinforce that, and upgrade something else; and, of course, the perennial old one that they have been trotting out for some time-they would introduce work for the dole which would, in some way, be some significant saving when it has been costed by the Government at something like $300m in expenditure. Then right at the end of his speech out came the figure of $2,735m. That was the amount by which their policy would be more cost-efficient and more cost-effective than that which is enshrined in this legislation. Indeed, not one speaker on the other side of the House has endorsed that amount and not one speaker subsequently-there have been four-has suggested that there was any credibility in the figure he brought forward at all.

The honourable member for Cowper and the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron), in their most unctuous contributions, suggested that, if in the future Australia was to be occupied by some foreign power, the establishment of this legislation would in some way be used against us. The honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) and the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) talked about civil libertarian concepts. While the honourable member for North Sydney also did a bit of nitpicking about the costings-I have heard him in this place many times talk about civil liberties-I accept his contribution. But I cannot accept the suggestion from the honourable member for Richmond that in some way we were producing a big brother which would be looking over the shoulder of every Australian-a dossier on financial transactions which would be produced in respect of every Australian. I think it is necessary for us to understand that all the information about which members of the other side of the House were concerned is already available. The 8 1/2 million Australians who have a credit card have already given that information to a private organisation and the information is within the financial institutions, within the credit card companies, and is available and circulating.

We need to understand that there has been a profound change in society over the last 50 years. Now it is possible for people to travel across this country daily by air, by rail or by car. Fifty years ago the population was much more stable. People were less mobile. Even the growing cities had much more cohesive and small environments and, indeed, there were smaller suburbs and smaller towns. Business was transacted with people whom one knew. A cash system operated almost exclusively, and previously there was a barter system. It is only now that the majority of transactions that people undertake every day are anonymous. How does one trust a person one does not know? If one is in business, how does one establish a person's identity?

There are 8 1/2 million Australians who have a credit card. They have a credit card because they need identification. Reliable identity cards for commercial purposes are the business that credit card companies and banks are in. How do we get a credit card? We get one by releasing detailed personal information and establishing a satisfactory credit rating. Indeed, all that information, which is then available to those credit card companies and financial institutions, circulates. If members of the Opposition are concerned that all sorts of information will be in some way perverted by this legislation, they are completely off the point and miss the thrust of this legislation completely.

I ask honourable members: What if the Government was to set up an agency or public sector authority to collect and hold the following information on Australian citizens? I will read out this list: Their name and address and a personal identifying number; their age; a full history of addresses where they have lived; people with whom they have lived; various occupations they have followed; names of all who have employed them; how much they paid them; whether or not they have changed their name; the name of their spouse; whether they are married or divorced or widowed; whether they are living away from their spouse; the names and ages of their children; whether their children live with them; whether their children go to state or private schools; the details of any various pre-nuptial or ex-nuptial children; whether they are unmarried parents; any periods of unemployment or sickness; what social welfare payments they have received; the names of trusts and partnerships of which they are members; the names of any companies of which they are directors and any remuneration they receive; the details of all institutions in which they hold funds; the identity of companies in which they hold shares; any life assurance policies; a description of all property owned by them; when it was acquired and what it was sold for; its purchase price; its sale price; any profit made on its sale; any interest held in any property or business outside Australia; the location of the property; a description of it; the names and addresses of any companies, trusts or partnerships outside Australia in which they have an interest. I can go on and on: The names of any trade unions, businesses or professional associations of which they are members; the annual membership fees; the names of organisations and institutions which they support financially; and, if they have had high medical expenses, the details of all illnesses and treatments, including psychiatric treatment.

If we were to set up some sort of public institution to gather all that information, I am sure we would hear haranguing from the other side of the House and all sorts of cries about civil libertarian views. But as most people will have realised, what I have just given them is a list of the information which is already held by the Australian Taxation Office. Yet people on the other side of the House are trying to tell us that this identity card in some way infringes the civil liberties of Australian citizens. The Australian Taxation Office already holds all that information. The question here is a balance between the benefits to the community of a proposed course of action and the possible threat to individual liberties. I cannot imagine how anybody can suggest that giving one's name and surname, a photograph of a person, a signature, date of birth, sex and residential and postal address means that this card infringes on civil liberties. Indeed, the Government has for a long time accepted the view that it is legislating in many areas for the benefit of citizens and at times infringes on their liberties. We accept that there has to be a balance between those two things. It is necessary for us to look at areas where this occurs already.

Let us look at the Australian Customs Service. We accept that it is the right of a Customs officer to search someone coming into Australia. Perhaps he is importing something illegal-perhaps wild life, drugs, or animal matter-which in some way can infringe on, or be of harm to, the community as a whole. We accept that it is reasonable for the Government to legislate in that way. We accept that when we go away on an aeroplane we can be searched because we understand the problem with hijacking and the fact that people may be carrying weapons, concealed drugs or whatever. We accept it as reasonable for governments to legislate so that, if we drive over the speed limit, a policeman can stop us and ask to see our drivers licence, that he can perhaps test us on the possible level of alcohol in our blood, and that he can make some sort of statement as to whether we were or were not wearing a seat-belt. In many areas we accept the balance between the community interest and the interest of the individual. The suggestion that the legislation in some way infringes on that is absurd and arrant nonsense.

It is necessary for members of the Opposition to drag themselves out of the Middle Ages and to appreciate that it is important to have an effective identification system. Almost every democracy in continental Europe requires an identity card or unique ID number. In 1936 the United States of America established a system involving a social security number. A similar system operates in Canada. There have been great criticisms of the systems in the United States and Canada because their systems are of low integrity and have been shown to be inefficient. Why were those systems established? Why was it that in the United States in 1936 it became necessary to establish a social security number system? Clearly, following the Great Depression, governments became aware of the necessity to provide entitlements to those who were in hardship. There was an expansion in entitlements. Public relief and public insurance programs became available. Social security insurance and dependent children's aid became available. Assistance for the unemployed, the disabled, the aged and veterans became available. It was necessary for governments to identify those who were entitled to those benefits and, in some way, make sure that those benefits were paid to those who had the entitlement.

Unfortunately, the United States system was one of low integrity. It was necessary, to establish a social security number, only for a person to declare that he thought he had an entitlement. As a consequence, forgery, tampering and abuse are rampant in the United States. The United States system is inefficient and ineffective.

We have the opportunity, by establishing this legislation, to avoid the mistakes of other countries and to have a high integrity, much more efficient system. That is the thrust of the legislation. I cannot imagine why the Opposition cannot understand that it is the responsibility of this Government, and of us in this Parliament, to ensure that the money which the Government raises is raised fairly and that the money which the Government spends is spent efficiently and in the right way.

Five months ago the Opposition had no policies. Now it has a mish-mash of policies such as: `We will tighten this, reinforce that, perhaps upgrade something and perhaps introduce a scheme to make people work for the dole'. However, the Opposition still does not have a policy in this area. It is important for us to understand that it is necessary for the Government to make these savings and to ensure that government money is spent effectively.

There is another aspect to the legislation which is important and which some people have not talked about; that is, the deterrent effect which will accrue from the establishment of the Australia Card. It is clear that there are an estimated 60,000 illegal immigrants in the country. Those people are in this country contrary to the laws. It is an affront to those who are patiently waiting to go through the proper procedures. It is important to understand that, once illegal immigrants are in this country, they are often exploited by unscrupulous employers; they escape the tax system; and, at other times, they make demands on social security and Medicare. By establishing the Australia Card we will make it more difficult for them to be employed. We will control financial transactions and we will protect the welfare and Medicare systems from fraud by those people. It will be a major deterrent to illegal immigration and it will be a way in which we can certainly save significant amounts of money in that area, if not stop this occurring.

It is important to consider the effect of the Australia Card on crime. Two royal commissions recommended that banks require greater proof of identity and that identity procedures had to be tightened. While there is a great deal of money in the cash economy in the area of organised and, I suppose, disorganised crime, we must understand that organised crime has money in other areas. The Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union stated:

Criminals seek to possess wealthy homes, land, expensive cars, yachts, and incur high living expenses . . . they may pay for much by cash; but ultimately . . . they find the normal financial institutions far more convenient and seemingly no less safe to use . . . this leads to the creation of large accounts with many taxation vouchers. Once located, those vouchers provide a fertile source of intelligence to the investigator.

Clearly, the establishment of the Australia Card will play a part in rooting out those who are involved in organised crime. It will not be necessary for people to carry the card every day. It is not every day that one buys a property, opens a bank account or engages a new stockbroker. It may be the case for some members of the Opposition, but it certainly is not for the ordinary Australian. It is not even every day that one has to visit a doctor. Indeed, all of those functions will require the production of the Australia Card. There will be no penalty for unintentional clerical errors. The Card will not infringe on privacy. All of those things are red herrings that have been drawn across the path by members of the Opposition.

The Opposition has tried to find reasons for opposing the Australia Card. It says that there will be the manufacture of false ID cards. Perhaps we should not have cash available, because it is possible to forge money. Perhaps credit cards should not be used because it is possible to forge credit cards. They do not have the same integrity that this system will have. In all of those cases, there is a belief that the benefits outweigh the costs. Australians can see that this is an honest attempt by the Government to improve the efficiency with which we collect money through the Australian Taxation Office and to make the system fairer. It is an honest attempt to make sure that the expenditure in many of our programs is paid to those who deserve and are entitled to it. I have great pleasure in endorsing the legislation. I hope that it will gain the support of the Opposition not only in this place but also in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this opportunity to speak on such a vital issue as the Australia Card Bill 1986 (No. 2), given that this autocratic and authoritarian socialist Government so unceremoniously gagged my speech during the last debate. I would like to commend the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) for his compassionate understanding of the evil implications and evil potential of such an insidious Bill as that currently being debated in this place. The principles of liberty, equality, justice and humanity are the foundation stones upon which a free and democratic society are built and the guarantees and safeguards on which its continued existence depends.

SPEECH.PARA: This debate today is not so much about whether we can or should introduce a compulsory national identification system but whether we are prepared to ignore and undermine these basic democratic principles. The acceptance of the one concept is, in the final analysis, the rejection of the others. There may be persuasive and seemingly very reasonable arguments used to justify the implementation of the Government's Australia Card proposal, but they must be considered very carefully against the arguments in favour of preserving and maintaining the rights and privileges that Australians are indeed fortunate to enjoy--

TALK.START.PARA: —A free society.

—A free society; one that we must move, at all expense, to guarantee now and in future, and which we must be vigilant to protect-rights and privileges which are unknown, denied or restricted in many other countries, but which we take almost for granted; our personal privacy, civil liberties and individual freedoms. Perhaps it is because we have become rather complacent that we are sometimes slow to recognise when these most precious principles and ideals are being threatened and we are hesitant in our reactions to defend our rights, because it is not always immediately obvious how they are under attack. We have them now, so we presume that we will always have them. Such presumptions are dangerously naive and demonstrably incorrect. The greatest dangers lie not in the obviously easily identifiable threats but in the apparantly innocent, inconsequential actions which are promoted as being fair, necessary and beneficial. The idea of giving a little to gain a lot is an attractive and simple proposition to market, but sometimes even a little is far too much. A little given or taken frequently soon amounts to a lot more than may have been originally anticipated.

SPEECH.PARA: James Madison once observed: `There are more instances of the abridgement of the freedom of the people by gradual and silent encroachments of those in power than by violent and sudden usurpations'. Slowly whittled away, bit by bit, or sledge-hammered into oblivion with one well directed blow the result is the same. The former approach is, of course, more subtle than the latter and much harder to detect, but it is only a different means by which to achieve the same end.

This proposed legislation to introduce a national identification register is being sold to us on the basis that it will provide a workable, practical and acceptable solution to the significant and increasing problems of tax evasion, health and welfare fraud, organised crime, drug trafficking, illegal immigration, and a plethora of other undesirable and offensive activities; activities which are practiced by those who contrive and who are determined to abuse in uncommonly bad ways a system which has been designed, however imperfectly, to serve the common good. There can be no denying that problems do exist, but the introduction of a compulsory identification card is not a proper nor an acceptable solution.

This legislation will allow the State and the bureaucracy to abrogate the rights of the many in the hope that they may apprehend the despicable and selfish few. As a result, the vast majority of decent, honest, law abiding citizens will be dispossessed of their personal privacy and will have their irreplaceable rights and privileges downgraded, thus increasing their vulnerability to the big brother scenario which was once considered implausible but which is now becoming a frightening reality.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under Labor.

—Under Labor now and under any subsequent Labor soclialist government. Hopefully, we have seen the last of them. To excuse and justify this dangerous proposal by claiming that it will clean up the corrupt, criminal and parasitic elements in our society is a confidence trick of monstrous proportions. The Government is well aware of these facts and has therefore sought to ignore them in its ID card marketing campaign by adopting yet again the `politics of envy' tactic-the shoddy and shallow strategy of emphasising and concentrating on the `let's get even' aspects of its insidious scheme. If it really wants to get even it can start doing so now by instructing the appropriate authority to use the existing legislation in a more efficient and therefore more effective manner. The `get even' measures already exist, but they are not being used.

SPEECH.PARA: Why do we need more laws when the ones we have now are not being given a chance to work. If the Government is really genuine in its desire to beat the cheats and those who exploit the system, and can demonstrate that it has tried to overcome the problems but is being defeated by the inadequacies of existing legislation let it tighten up the system and the legislation. But any tightening must be by fair rather than by foul means. Let it improve and strengthen existing laws and regulations. But at the same time it must realise its actions will be futile unless it also ensures that resources are available whereby these measures can be and are enforced. The only real deterrent to those who contrive to break the law is the certainty of being caught and suitably punished. After all this has been done, if specific problem areas still remain, only then should we contemplate introducing new and additional legislation. But we must always remember that evil practices cannot and will not be overcome by evil laws. Therefore, any new laws will be acceptable only if they are good laws, and good laws are ones that work only to the detriment of, have an adverse influence or effect upon, or reduce the rights and privileges of those who break and abuse them.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a bad law.

—This is indeed a bad law. The Australia Card legislation is not, by any definition, the basis for a good law. It will not provide proper and adequate solutions to the difficult problems of graft, corruption and greed which manifest themselves in the spiralling white and blue collar crime rates which currently confront us. This Government maintains that it wants to protect the rights of the people, yet it sets about doing so by proposing legislation which restricts those rights. It is very easy to protect rights by restricting them. We need only have a few laws based on this premise and we will have no rights left to protect. The problem will then have solved itself. Furthermore, the instigators of this Orwellian legislation have the temerity to endeavour to disguise their true intentions under a mask of respectability by calling the seemingly innocuous, but nonetheless obnoxious, plastic identity tag, the Australia Card.

SPEECH.PARA: There would be very few things less Australian in concept and character than a compulsory identity card. The proposal is totally un-Australian in design, in principle, and in practice. The Hawke Government is being altogether rather too coy. It should demonstrate the courage of its convictions by being brutally frank and honest by calling this small but powerful machine made computer controlled menace `the personal privacy invader'-that is what it really is.

Many honourable members opposite who support the Australia Card proposal may be well-meaning, well-intentioned and sincerely motivated by a desire to put a stop to the unwelcome activities of undesirable and irresponsible people who do not pay their taxes, or who rob the public purse of millions of dollars each year, but they are lacking in foresight and understanding if they imagine that this legislation is the best solution. In fact, it is a far greater abuse of the rights of ordinary Australian citizens than could ever result from the activities of all the tax evaders and dole cheats combined. This is truly an instance where the hackneyed phrase about the cure being worse than the disease can be justifiably employed.

The legislation we are debating today is littered with uncertainties and fraught with dangers. It may be presented to us with assurances that its very real potential for abuse and exploitation will never be authorised and, therefore, never realised. Such promises are easy to make and just as easy to break. Let it be clearly understood by every Australian that there is and can be no absolute and/or permanent guarantee that present or future governments will not or cannot amend the so-called safeguards that may now be contained in the proposed legislation, but which can be altered or deleted by any government of any political persuasion which has the inclination and the numbers so to do. It will be a relatively simple matter to link up the various mushrooming data banks which hold information, often information of a very personal and private nature about you and me and all Australians and combine and exchange this data at will.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics, which has been given increasing authority to pry into the day to day affairs of unsuspecting citizens who have already been deprived of the right to refuse to participate in its inquistorial activities, is potentially a very valuable and, therefore, highly vulnerable source of information. The ABS holds not only details compulsorily acquired from Australians during the Census, but also it collects an enormous amount of information on an ongoing basis. None of this relevant and sensitive data is provided anonymously.

Medicare maintains files on every Australian who has lodged a claim for medical or hospital expenses; all highly confidential, all highly vulnerable. There are many instances, several in my electorate of Casey, where the confidentiality of the patient-doctor relationship has been breached by Medicare investigators. Information and records about patients and their illnesses are obviously readily available to Medicare employees and, via them, to the police and other authorities, all without prior knowledge or consent of the patient.

The Australian Taxation Office is another agency which holds a substantial amount of confidential information about a lot of people, most of whom have no intention of breaking any laws or offending against any regulations. The Taxation Office has significant and far-reaching powers which enable its inspectors and investigators to obtain and use information without knowledge or consent of the taxpayers or taxpayers involved. It is unfortunately a matter of public record that the Taxation Office is sometimes more efficient in leaking information than it is in collecting it.

These three agencies alone have the potential to provide detailed, confidential and personal information which could be used to prepare exhaustive profiles on any or all of the people who are already on their files-and that is most of us. There is, however, no guarantee as to the accuracy of this information or whether or not adequate provisions exist to allow errors to be rectified. There can certainly be no guarantee that the various departments have the ability or even the commitment or intention, to maintain total permanent confidentiality in regard to their files.

The Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card, with members from all the major political parties, has rigorously examined all aspects of the Australia Card proposal and has rejected the proposed legislation as being inappropriate, unjustifiable and unacceptable. After assessing evidence for and against the ID card the Committee voted five to three against the Goverment's proposals. One of those against included one of the Government's members.

TALK.START.PARA: —He had principles.

—One of the very few. The findings of the Committee, plus evidence and information available from other countries where some form of ID card is used, proved beyond doubt that the Government's proposal is ill-advised and misguided. The Australia Card will not provide efficient, cost-effective, workable or proper solutions to the difficult problems that currently exist. It will, however, undoubtedly destroy or encroach upon many of our fundamental rights and freedoms.

SPEECH.PARA: Faced with all the indisputable evidence of the present vulnerability and shortcomings of the system and the potentially disastrous consequences for society as we know it if this or any future government decides to change its mind about what will and will not be included in the Australia Card Register, the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) still maintains that one must question the motives of those who oppose the Australia Card proposal. I respectfully and sincerely suggest that one must instead be questioning the motives of those who wish to impose it. It is not a matter of what those who oppose the system are trying to get away with, but what those who would oppose the system are trying to do away with.

TALK.START.PARA: —Freedom.

—Freedom is such a rare commodity in this difficult world. As children we often played two innocent and entertaining games: `Who am I', where the clues are revealed one by one until at last there is no doubt in anybody's mind as to who the person in question is; and `I spy', where persistent questioning is used to uncover the identity of the thing or person being spied upon. Suddenly these games do not seem so innocent and entertaining anymore, now that the Government wants to play and is prepared to legislate so that it and its agencies will be the ones asking the questions, with the rest of us having no choice but to provide the answers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australia Card is but another weapon in this Government's armouring in the perpetual war against tax cheats and those who rip off the social security system, or those who trample on our immigration laws. We knew from the outset that this attack would create controversy and the fallout would be diversity, but surely as a government we are obliged to put in place a tax system based on fairness and equity and to ensure that we extend benefits only to those who deserve them. Obviously the Government is faced with the need to balance that against any possible threat to civil liberties and privacy that could be created by the introduction of a universal identification system. Poll after poll has shown that this initiative is long overdue and there is wide public support. After all, the public has been taken to the cleaners for nearly 30 years. It clearly reflects the community's concern about tax cheats who have been protected by those opposite when in government, whose philosophy of tax reform was clearly predicted on the very simple dictum that tax was made optional for the rich.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me destroy some sacred myths revered by my friends opposite, who claim to be the custodians of our civil liberties and guardians of our privacy. It is sheer hypocrisy. I put one pertinent question: Where do they stand, for instance, on the issue of private data banks, particularly those relating to credit reference information? We are all aware of the massive growth of data bases in the private enterprise area. For example, banks routinely double check with other banks information given on loan applications, without customer approval. We are all aware of the two-way trading of credit information that occurs within the computer system.
The minority report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card, referring to the question of technology, had this to say:

In short absolute privacy does not exist in a society which has up-to-date technology and accepts the use of that technology. If one is born, marries or begets children, if one buys or sells a house or land, if one borrows money, if one votes or receives an award wage, and if one pays tax, one is on a file somewhere and technology is already being used to draw those separate items of information together.

This Government's decision to establish a data protection agency to protect individual privacy against the misuse of government files is a step in the right direction. Similarly, logging access of the Australia Card Register is a new element in privacy protection. It will require a public servant wanting to see a person's Australia Card file to record each request, together with the reason for wanting that access. Access to the Register cannot be obtained until those requirements have been met. Professor Whalan of the Australian National University, a noted civil libertarian, said in evidence to the Committee:
Perhaps one irony would be that if we do have an Australia Card with all those protections . . . our privacy may be better protected than it is now.

When opponents talk about the capacity of criminals to defeat the challenge posed by the card, they forget one consistent trait of those who reap high financial rewards from all illegal activities. That trait is the compulsion to maintain a lifestyle commensurate with the rewards. Real estate is bought, legal investments are made and cash is generally converted to assets or investments, all creating a money trail that will be easy to follow with a universal identification system such as that proposed by the card. The Australian Taxation Office will then be able to link all sources of income to one number. My friend Commissioner Costigan put it perhaps more cogently when he said:

Criminals seek to possess wealthy homes, land, expensive cars, yachts and incur high living expenses . . . They may pay for much much by cash; but ultimately . . . they find the normal financial institutions far more convenient and seemingly no less safe to use . . . this leads to the creation of large accounts with many taxation vouchers. Once located, those vouchers provide a fertile source of intelligence to the investigator.
I say to honourable members opposite that we want to follow the money trail. That will take a lot of courage, physically and legislatively.

TALK.START.PARA: —Costigan opposes the Australia Card because he believes it is ineffective.

—I disagree with him on that but I respect his opinion. Let me separate fact from fiction. We have not had too much fact tonight from the Opposition. In simple terms, the Australia Card is the medium on which a person's Australia Card number will be recorded. The card will be used in the verification of identity of all persons. That is the key to it. It will apply in the following: Opening and operating accounts with financial institutions; making investments; receiving income from cash management, property and unit trusts; receiving primary production income through produce agents and marketing authorities; receiving rents through real estate agents; making foreign remittances; buying real estate; operating safe deposit boxes; buying shares and receiving dividends; dealing in futures contracts; receiving salaries or wages; and receiving income subject to the prescribed payments system.

SPEECH.PARA: This measure is long overdue. The wage and salary earners in this country have carried the load for far too long. This measure will lead to greater levels of compliance with taxation laws by ensuring that persons cannot open accounts or transact business in false names. Evasion of tax by the use of accounts in false names is not limited to tax on interest received. The capital often comes from a taxable source. By reason of the card having to be produced when a person opens an account or continues an account beyond the second relevant day, the opening of accounts in false names will be blocked off. Existing identification procedures by banks have failed-I stress that-to prevent the widespread use of accounts in false names.

Other critical areas include the matching of information reports to the Tax Office. The card number will facilitate efficient matching of information received by the Tax Office with taxpayers' records. Information reported to the Tax Office is currently based on names and addresses. That requires significant resources to enable the matching of the information with returns of taxpayers. The problem in the area of information relating to interest, for example, lies not in ensuring that all interest payments are reported but in correctly matching reported interest payments with the returns of the taxpayers who derived interest. I do not know how many years I have been battling for that. Only about one-half of the interest reported to the Tax Office is correctly matched with taxpayers' returns. Matching problems arise not only because of accounts in false names but also because of spelling errors, transposition errors, use of abbreviated names, different forms of persons' names, common names, name changes and differing addresses. These problems can be overcome only by a unique identifier.

What are the alternatives peddled by Opposition members. One is to upgrade the tax file number. This was at best an innovative and shoddy alternative useful only to get them off the hook when they realised just how popular the Australia Card was in the general community. Another alternative peddled by the Opposition is the hullabaloo we heard tonight from every Opposition speaker of improving the Tax Office, making it `do its job'. I have been here quite a while. I suppose there is nobody in this Parliament who has done more to try to reform the tax system than I have in my humble way. For 30 out of the last 36 years the people opposite were in government and in the specific area of reform in the Tax Office the Opposition has a track record as barren as the Saraha Desert. It is an appalling record.

No doubt my friends opposite have applied their minds to the following messy and unpalatable alternatives to overcome tax evasion. Let us have a look at the proposal the Opposition has floated to some extent concerning the withholding tax system. It will be necessary to look at each category of income to which withholding tax arrangements could apply-for example, interest, the most readily adaptable of all categories of income-to a withholding tax system. However, there are still some problems to consider. For example, there would still be an incentive to evade tax unless tax was withheld at the highest marginal rate. I would like some discussion opposite on that. Extension of the withholding tax system to rental income would result in tenants being required to deduct tax from rent due to their landlord and to remit that tax to the Taxation Office.

As we all know, a withholding tax system presently applies in the case of salaries and wages and prescribed payments. However, the Australia Card will result in a further $142m tax being collected in respect of these categories of income. It has been estimated that the Australia Card program, when fully operational, will recover $724m which would otherwise be evaded. I refer to three components of that. For instance, it is anticipated that from accounts with financial institutions there will be a recovery of $190m; from business income, primary producers and rental income, $119m; and from employment, including the prescribed payment system, about $142m. What has not been touched on by many speakers tonight but what is of vital interest to many people in the community is that the Australia Card will be an invaluable weapon in the armoury against the appalling escalation of illicit drug trafficking in this country.

I wish to take a few minutes to quote an extract from a speech I made on income tax Bills last year. I say to my friends opposite that the Australia Card is nothing more than one weapon in the armoury against tax cheats but I say sincerely that what is needed in the whole area is a multifaceted approach. It is not just a question of tidying up the Tax Office; it is not just a question of putting an ID card in place; it stretches right across the whole judicial system and the legislative system. We have taken a long time in this country to get a Commonwealth evidentiary Act. It is one of the weaknesses of the system. We ought to have a special division of the Federal Court to deal with breaches of commercial law.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?
—That is a very interesting question. In this country there has been an appalling record of dealing with pin-stripe crime in the corporate area.
—But the courts have dealt with it.

—Have they? I shall give a classic example. I remember when the collapse of the Cambridge Credit Corporation Ltd took place 11 years ago. We say that the laws are in place. It has taken us more than eight years to get a common accounting standards procedure. We are still struggling to get that.
—But it is not the courts.
—It is the laws.
—Yes, it's the laws, not the courts.

—State courts invested with Federal jurisdiction, judges that sit on complex commercial fraud cases, are not really skilled to deal with complex fraud cases. That is one of the reasons why the banks in England went to the Government and asked the Roskill committee to look at the problem of spivs and charlatans ripping off the system because the court system could not cope with it. There is a lot of discussion in this country on the need for what we are talking about tonight. We need a multifaceted approach. We need effective legislation at a Federal level to deal with pin-stripe crime. We will not do that with the current co-operative system that is based on the lowest common denominator approach.

SPEECH.PARA: There was an appalling spectacle with Cambridge Credit 11 years ago-the biggest corporate collapse that I can remember in recent years. It has taken the Corporate Affairs Commission in New South Wales 11 years to put its act together. Three weeks or a month ago we saw the appalling spectacle of a judge-I would not criticise the decision-ruling the case out on the basis of the 11 years it took the Corporate Affairs Commission to compile the case against the directors of the company. I think that is a travesty of justice. We cannot do much for shareholders in Cambridge Credit, but surely we have an obligation to protect debenture holders and creditors. There is a whole stream of cases in this country which we have failed to do anything about at a Federal level. My view is that the sooner we bring in Federal legislation in the companies, securities and takeovers areas and the futures market, the sooner we will bring stability to the system and stamp out a whole variety of rorts and ramps in it.

Getting back to the identity card, why do we always demand accreditation from those who go to social service offices to get social service benefits? Why do we always put stringencies on the poor, but never demand accreditation from the rich? I could never understand that. I do not know for how many years we have tried to get bank regulations tightened up to ensure that every person pays his reasonable level of tax. We have had nothing but struggle with the banks, for as long as I have been here, to update regulations and make them more effective. The one thing that will make them more effective is matching between the two groups, the Australian Taxation Office and the banks. We will have to come around to that. I hope that we finally get it. The answers provided to questions on the Notice Paper the other day shows that at least we have come some of the way.

Insofar as opposition to this card in this Parliament is concerned, tax evaders, welfare cheats, drug traffickers and illegal immigrants will applaud the Opposition from one end of the country to the other. But the ordinary taxpayers and the honest citizens of this country will regard the Opposition with the contempt it deserves. For far too long the taxpayers, the ordinary wage and salary earners, have carried the burden. The fight in the community about tax reform is squarely about the question of tax equity. For as long as I have been in this Parliament the philosophies of the conservatives have been predicated on one simple dictum: They believe in reform, provided it changes nothing. They are great on tax reform but very weak on specific tax reform measures. I have a very simple dictum that I apply to tax reform, which has stood the test of time well. My friends opposite have never liked it. I have always believed in the very simple dictum: To afflict the comfortable and comfort the afflicted. It is with pleasure that I support this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill before us is called the Australia Card Bill, but I do not intend to use that term throughout this discussion. I intend to call the card what it is, that is, a straight-out identity card. Even the name itself is part of the pseudo-patriotic dressing-up of this legislation. No amount of green and gold will camouflage the grey, intrusive nature of bureaucracy associated with this card.
—The name is a fraud.

—The name is a fraud, as is everything else that goes with the card. The previous Government speaker, the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi), indicated that the Government sees in this proposal great merit in dealing with problems in the areas of welfare fraud, tax evasion and illegal immigration. I intend to address quite specifically the problems which exist in those areas and how the resolution of those problems was perceived by the joint parliamentary committee which looked at this proposal. I will also address arguments which have been presented subsequently in relation to this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: It is now a matter of record that the identity card proposal was rejected by a majority of the committee. It was rejected for very good reasons. In relation to welfare fraud, the Department of Social Security's evidence was that it believed that the matter of identity was not significant in prosecuting or investigating welfare fraud. It said that the principal problem in relation to fraud is the matter of overpayment and that the percentage of fraud perpetrated through the use of false identity in minimal. The Department went on to say that it believes that unless the security of the card is absolute the identity card may exacerbate the degree of fraud because once there is a card in existence it allows access to the entire system, which weakens the system even further. So the identity card, rather than being a means of cleaning up welfare fraud, could be the very vehicle by which welfare fraud could be extended. In its present form the card will not rectify the Department's major problem of people supplying false information on their income levels and domestic circumstances. So the evidence of the Department of Social Security given to the joint parliamentary committee overwhelmingly rejects the proposition that the card can be of any value in cleaning up welfare fraud.

Further to that, just before Christmas last year the annual report of the Director of Public Prosecutions was brought down. It indicated again that welfare fraud is not being effectively controlled. It is interesting to go to the very reasons why the Director of Public Prosecutions said that that was not happening. He said that major welfare fraud was not being investigated properly because the Australian Federal Police did not have the resources to take up major cases in that area. The Director of Public Prosecutions cannot move in that area unless he has data and material provided by the AFP to go on. If this Government had not starved the Australian Federal Police of the effective resources to move in the area we would not be faced with this problem. Again, in relation to welfare fraud we have a rejection of the proposition that an identity card will solve any part of the problem at all. One has to go back to the base level and make sure that the major fraud in that area is properly investigated. One will not get any distance down the track unless one gives the Australian Federal Police the appropriate resources to investigate major fraud and then gives the necessary referred leads to the Director of Public Prosecutions to take matters further. They are the areas to fix up first, before one starts looking at fanciful propositions such as an identity card.

Much nonsense has also been talked about illegal immigration. Anyone familiar with the problem of illegal immigration will know that the location of many illegal immigrants is well known to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The Australian Federal Police formerly had responsibility for moving in this area, responsibility which they no longer have because it has been handed over to untrained clerks in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to pursue. A sweep down Little Bourke Street in Melbourne, through the Chinese restaurants, would clean up many illegal immigrants. Likewise in Sydney, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs or the Australian Federal Police could move tonight and round up 600 illegal immigrants, because they know where they are. But what is the point? Then one gets into the long, drawn-out appeal procedures that have been set up over the years and finds that the Minister and the Department are unable to take any action against them. The location of many illegals is well known. The problem is not a matter of identity. Their identity and location are known. The problem relates to the fact that there is a lack of will and resources to do something about them and a lack of political will to overcome the cumbersome administrative practices and appeal procedures that are now in place to prevent them from being deported or other action being taken against them. That is the essential problem with illegal immigration. It is not the lack of an identity card. It is the fact that there is no will to do anything about the problem.

Again we have heard much about how an identity card will solve the problems in the tax evasion area. Yet is quite clear from the report of the Auditor-General and the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, of which I was proud to be a member some years ago--

TALK.START.PARA: —And a very good one.

—Thank you; that is quite correct. The reports put down by those two bodies clearly indicate that the reason a lot of tax is not collected at the moment is the inadequate procedures in the Australian Taxation Office, particularly in relation to the collection of tax on interest and dividends which could be more effectively carried out if the ATO had appropriate resources and more modern procedures and practices. Again, an ID card is a red herring. It has nothing to do with the collection of ad- ditional tax.
—They can't even get a tax return from the Treasurer.

—That is correct. The Taxation Office cannot even collect the tax return from our highly dubious Treasurer (Mr Keating). So how on earth will it pick up the revenue lost elsewhere in other areas in this country? If we look at the evidence overseas, we find that the issue of identity cards has been pursued by a number of countries, and quite unsucessfully.

SPEECH.PARA: The very sad thing about Australia is that so often we have this unfortunate habit that, 10 to 15 years after something has been implemented overseas and failed, it becomes trendy and fashionable to try it out here. We have had all sorts of models perpetrated over the years. The gentlemen on the other side are very fond of the Swedish model. Other people are fond of the Canadian model, other European models and the American model. Once an idea has been tried out in other countries and has flopped, the bureaucracy here, a decade later, picks it up and wants to implement the same idea here, at the same time as those overseas are trying to get out of theirs.

In the United States of America it is conservatively estimated that the forgery of social security cards currently costs $15 billion a year. That is a conservative estimate. Some estimates put it even higher at $20 billion or even higher. On the matter of the United States social security card, it is always interesting to note that, every time the United States Federal Bureau of Investigation picks up a drug courier, it finds that he is carrying six, seven, a dozen or more social security cards. So in the United States, social security cards apply across the whole population, with the law abiding majority using them and abiding by the rules. But those intent on breaking the law use them as a vehicle to further their intentions in that area. So there is a dragnet across the whole population, as is now proposed here, but the minority who are intent on breaking the law use the United States social security card as a means of furthering their illicit intentions in the areas in which they are interested.

In Sweden, where there is a national identity system, it is estimated at the moment that the system still fails to prevent something like a 20 per cent loss of revenue to the black economy-a one-fifth loss of revenue to the black economy in Sweden today despite the fact that it has had in place for many years a very long established and very extensive identity system.

Going back to the United States, it is also interesting to note that the United States Federal Advisory Committee on False Identification was strongly opposed to the introduction of a national identity card on the basis that it could benefit criminals and be beneficial to organised crime. That is obviously the case from what I said a few moments ago-that every time a drug courier is picked up in the United States, he is carrying multiple identity cards and has a different pseudonym that he uses in different areas of the United States as he moves around.

If we go further down the track, we are aware too that the Australian Bankers Association believes, and has believed for some time, that, unless quite significant changes are made to the identity card legislation proposed here, a number of basic bank transactions will become unworkable. For instance, it says that credit card transactions, the acceptance of periodic payments such as pension cheques and the transfer of funds and cash withdrawals through access to automatic teller machines will all become unworkable. These views of the Australian Bankers Association were updated in the Age newspaper of only a week ago, Tuesday 17 March, when again the banks warned the Government that, unless some fairly substantial changes are made to the legislation, there is no way that the legislation could possibly work. In fact, Mr Alan Cullen, the Director of the Australian Bankers Association, said that the card's introduction would cost the banks between $60m and $70m in setting-up costs and a further $5m a year to run. So the banks have been quite consistent in their view that this system will have great difficulty in operating.

Furthermore, as we are well aware, it has been estimated conservatively that the cost to the taxpayer of setting up this entire system will be $1 billion over 10 years-the cost of the new Parliament House, I point out-and it will require as a minimum 2,000 new Federal public servants to operate the system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just what we want!

—That is right; that is just what we want when we are trying to get the costs of the public sector down! They are the conservative estimates at the moment. But what will the cost be some years down the track, if this proposal gets off the ground? I do not think anyone really knows. Then we have the general estimate of a cost to business of $2 billion over a 10-year period for the implementation and setting up of the system. At a time when business is trying to cut costs to survive in both the rural and urban areas of this country, and at a time when we are trying to cut down public sector costs, we are talking about putting $1 billion extra onto the taxpayers, $2 billion extra on business and an extra 2,000 public servants. It is just unbelievable.

SPEECH.PARA: One other area to which I wish to turn is the matter of privacy. Regrettably, this area has not received the attention that it deserves. Of course, people have been naturally concerned with the costs and the mechanics of the administrative implementation of the proposal. The privacy area has tendered to be ignored. I think this is the great sleeper out in the community from many of the comments that have been made to me. There is a silent majority out there who are far more concerned about the privacy implications of this whole proposal than many people realise. As the debate runs further and further on, the privacy aspect will come to the surface more and more.

We are all well aware from evidence in the United States and also in this country of how insecure most computer systems are. We know from evidence in the United States, here and western Europe how easily amateur computer hackers can break into computer systems, including the computer systems of some major corporate structures. If amateur computer hackers can get into a system, why cannot organised crime? In fact, Frank Costigan and Doug Meagher, both associated with the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, both pointed out the potential benefit of an identity card system to organised crime. That is why Frank Costigan QC has so strongly opposed the identity card proposal. Because of his involvement in the Royal Commission and his subsequent interest, he has certainly expressed great concern about the problem of organised crime. But he does not see the identity card as a way out of the problem.

It is interesting also to note that another interested party, the Australian Federal Police, has grave doubts about the effectiveness of an identity card. In fact some of its members have said to me: `If we could have but a fraction of the resources that will be devoted to setting up the ID card system, we could achieve so much more in cracking down on illegal immigration and welfare fraud'. By being selective, and with just a fraction of the financial and manpower resources that will go to setting up the ID card system, so much more could be achieved. In fact, probably one of the great problems of this proposal is that it is not selective enough. It is a dragnet across the whole population. It is like taking a sledge-hammer to crack nuts. The way to get to grips with problems such as illegal immigration, tax evasion and social security fraud is by very selective and precise measures. One has to target exactly what one wants and go after it with a vengeance. Across the board measures are quite useless in that regard.

Returning to the area of privacy, this leads me to express concern about where this proposal will take us in the longer term. We know that when the proposal was first mooted only a small number of Federal departments asked for access to the card. But, as the deliberations of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card went on, greater numbers of departments started requesting the right to be accessed to the card. I can see that, once this system is set up, over a period of time, with successive changes of government, we will get a greater body of the Federal bureaucracy asking to be accessed. It is no wonder that, for instance, Mr Justice Kirby, President of the New South Wales Court of Appeal, has been moved to say:
What is at stake is nothing less than the nature of our society, and the power and authority of the state in relation to the individual.
Mr Roger Clarke, Reader in Information Services at the Australian National University, also said:
. . . The Government had failed to demonstrate the overwhelming case necessary to justify such a `gross attack' on the fabric of Australian society.

That again comes back to the basic proposition that I mentioned before-that what is being attempted here is to put a dragnet across the whole population instead of approaching these problems in the precise, selective way in which they can be approached. In that regard it is worth looking at what could eventually happen over a period if the system is extended further.

I draw your attention to the Swedish system where a very extensive data bank is held on every Swedish citizen. I will just give a couple of case studies to show the potential abuse that exists. Last year a journalist went into the local county office of the town in which he was resident in Sweden and gave the name of a citizen. He was subsequently given the full name, address and personal identification number of that citizen. Using the personal identification number of that citizen and the personal identification number of that citizen's wife, the journalist was able to obtain the following information: Their tax returns from the tax office; details of birth from the parish office; vehicle details from the vehicle register; and copies of passport pictures, together with copies of their passport applications, which included their legal signatures-the perfect base for a forgery. That is how far down the track the Swedish system has got.

That system is now open to widespread external abuse. I quote parts of an article from the Swedish newspaper Expressen of 6 June 1986. The article was headlined `The Swedish Citizenry Register is abroad and is used by foreign countries among other things to check Swedes who apply for Visas'. The article stated:
When two Gotlanders-
Gotland is a small island off Sweden-
were picked up by the Soviet Coastguards in the spring of 1983 they were taken ashore for interrogation and identity control-all they needed to do was to give their personal identity numbers.

They handed over their PI numbers and everything about them immediately became available to the Soviet coastguards who picked them up. The Swedish system has got so far down the track that not only can anyone within Sweden obtain full data on any other Swedish citizen in relation to all the areas I described earlier when that journalist went into his local county office and started the whole process moving, but also people external to Sweden can now obtain all the information they want in relation to any Swedish citizen. Therefore, it is no wonder that the Swedes have been reviewing their system and have been thinking of ways to get out of it, but they do not quite know how to because they have gone so far down the track. The real reason for this legislation is so that the Government can try on an election if it wants to. All I say is: Let the Government come at it because its internal passport will become its pass out of office.
Debate (on motion by Mr Martin) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have raised in this House now on two occasions and I wish again to raise tonight the question of the attempt by the Hawke socialist Government to close down the Tasmanian forest industries. The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) presented legislation which went through this House last week. SPEECH.PARA: I have been back to look at the famous Gordon below Franklin case in the High Court of Australia. TALK.START.PARA: —So much for States' rights.

As my colleague the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), will well confirm, the Government does not give a damm about its vote in Tasmania. SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, did you know that of the 260,000 hectares that this all powerful, all dominating and all bullying Hawke socialist Goverment is trying to lock up we are not just talking about World Heritage but about the National Estate and about private property? It might upset the Minister but I want to say that his legislation contains four of the most totalitarian clauses ever brought before this Parliament. That right is given by this outrageous Government not just to members of the Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests but to any other person authorised in writing-ergo Jonathon West.

TALK.START.PARA: —In tonight's adjournment debate I take the opportunity to give an example of what I believe most politicians have-a sixth sense about psychology. Just before the outbreak of the Second World War one of the national leaders of Europe said:

SPEECH.PARA: For over five years this man has been chasing around Europe like a madman in search of something he could set on fire. Unfortunately, again and again he finds hirelings who open the gates of their country to this international incendiary.

On hearing this particular passage one automatically thinks of Adolf Hitler. However, this speech was made by Hitler about Churchill just before the outbreak of World War II. TALK.START.PARA: —It is my wish this evening to address the subject of the Australian Government's support for active economic sanctions against South Africa. He may be interested to learn, therefore, that in May of last year the entire Catholic hierarchy of Southern Africa, after three days of careful deliberation, came to what they described in their own words as a `decision of conscience' and proclaimed themselves to be in favour of international economic sanctions against South Africa. That decision was released in the form of a solemn pastoral letter to be read from the pulpit of each and every Catholic church in South Africa. Similar calls have, of course, been made by church leaders of other denominations. Furthermore, in this same pastoral letter the Catholic bishops called on the South African Government to release all imprisoned black political leaders, such as Nelson Mandela, and to lift bans on black organisations such as the African National Congress, of which Mandela is the leader.

On the question of black support for economic sanctions, I would simply refer the honourable member for Parkes to the results of a thoroughgoing survey conducted last September by Market and Opinion Research International and the South African company, Markinor. This survey was commissioned by the British newspaper, the Sunday Times. The results were published in its issue of Sunday, 3 August 1986. The survey indicated that in urban areas of South Africa, where it would seem the honourable member for Parkes spent considerable time, 47 per cent of blacks favoured sanctions and only 29 per cent were opposed. In the more conservative and less well-informed rural areas the picture is somewhat different. Twenty-two per cent of blacks favoured sanctions and 34 per cent were opposed to them. Of all blacks polled, 36 per cent had never had the opportunity to hear of economic sanctions. Overall, of those who were familiar with what economic sanctions involved, 46 per cent favoured sanctions and 51 per cent were opposed. There is every indication that within another year or so, unless there is some dramatic end to the whole system of apartheid, the majority of blacks will favour sanctions, and just possibly another poll today would find that this had already happened.

Another compelling fact to emerge from the survey is that Nelson Mandela, the jailed leader of the ANC, is most clearly the person most favoured by blacks to become the President of South Africa. The African National Congress has, for the past 28 years, called on the international community to impose economic sanctions against South Africa. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 8 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has he received advice pursuant to section 30 of the Australian Heritage Commission Act concerning Tasmanian woodchip export licences.
(2) What was the context of that advice in relation to the Lemonthyme State Forest and the forest south of Farmhouse Creek in South-West Tasmania.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Advice from the Australian Heritage Commission (AHC) dated 13 December 1985 referred to action which I had proposed in relation to negotiation of an agreement with the Tasmanian Government on woodchip export licences to be issued subject to certain conditions, including negotiation of the agreement. That advice referred to earlier (15 November 1985) correspondence from the AHC in which the Commission gave the following advice in relation to four national estate places which include Lemonthyme State Forest and the forest south of Farmhouse Creek in South-west Tasmania.

``Without detailed information on the proposed operations within these four areas, the Commission is unable to provide recommendations on the resolution of the conflict. However, the Commission has closely examined each of the four places and concluded that forestry operations could occur within parts of them, without adversely affecting their national estate significance, provided conditions are placed on the nature of these operations. These conditions will need to be set following discussions with the Tasmanian Forestry Commission.

Until meaningful discussions can occur, and agreement is reached over the conflict areas, the Commission cannot support any logging in these areas. This highlights the need for mechanisms to be put in place for ongoing consultative and conflict resolution''.

The 13 December advice reiterated the Commission's support for consultative arrangements of the sort proposed. A consultative process, specifically to ensure that national estate values are protected in forest management planning by the Tasmanian Forestry Commission, was subsequently agreed with the Tasmanian Government and embodied in the Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) signed on 12 June 1986.

However, in relation to my proposal that licences be issued, the 13 December advice put the view that certain areas, including the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests (which include Farmhouse Creek), should be excluded from logging operations due to their wilderness value. The AHC further recommended that a decision not be taken on the Lemonthyme at that stage and that it be given priority consideration under the consultative arrangements. It also recommended that forestry operations be excluded from the wilderness and primitive areas of concession areas within South West Tasmania (which includes Farmhouse Creek).

On 26 February 1987, the Government introduced legislation, relating to the Lemonthyme and Southern Forest areas, to establish a Commission of Inquiry to review the possible World Heritage properties of those areas. The Inquiry will also determine whether there are prudent and feasible alternatives to logging in areas found to have, or contribute to, World Heritage values.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Conquest Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 18 February 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are the recommendations of the Report of the Inquiry into the Distribution of Federal Roads Grants (Cameron Inquiry) dealing with revised principles for allocating grants based on a weighted combination of traffic volume indicators covering a range of complicated issues yet to be thoroughly tested against reliable data.
(2) Did the Cameron Inquiry acknowledge deficiencies in current roads database and computer modelling resources.

(3) Will he (a) defer consideration of the Cameron Inquiry recommendations for 1 year to enable the State road authorities and his Department to investigate fully and report on their data needs and (b) extend the current Australian Land Transport Program percentage distributions until 1988-89.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Cameron Report's recommendations for the allocation of funding under the Australian Land Transport Program (ALTP) are based on four indicators of road funding requirements that relate to traffic volume and road length. They are: axle loading, road occupancy, restoration and upgrading. These terms are described fully in the Report. The indicators are weighted in accordance with the Committee's view that Federal funding should cater for both restoration and upgrading needs in approximately equal proportions.

The Inquiry also recommended that the Federal Government should undertake a periodic review of data sources, and the weighting applied to the indicators in the light of Federal objectives. In making this recommendation the Report makes a number of suggestions for collection and improvement of the data.

Difficulties with data encountered by the Committee of Inquiry and the methods used to overcome them are fully documented in its Report. Where appropriate the Committee also conducted sensitivity tests to ensure that its conclusions were soundly based. I am not aware that the Committee had any problem with computer modelling resources.

(3) (a) and (b) Section 19 of the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Act requires the Minister for Transport to make a determination on the distribution of the unallocated 5.236 percentage points of ALTP funding for the period 1987-88 to 1989-90 inclusive by 31 March 1987. It therefore has not been possible to defer consideration of the Report's recommendations for one year.
